StudyObjective: To investigate the neural correlates of cognitive control processes using fMRI tasks and behavioral assessments.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: A classic inhibitory control task measuring both reaction time and error rates in response to no-go stimuli.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: In this study, the Go/No-Go task included 4 blocks, each with 30 trials. Each trial lasted 2 seconds, with a 1-second inter-trial interval. Subjects were instructed to press a button upon seeing 'go' stimuli and to refrain from pressing for 'no-go' stimuli.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Subjects rested with eyes open for baseline functional connectivity measurements.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants completed a 5-minute resting-state scan in a single continuous run, instructed to keep their eyes open and minimize movement.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A short-term memory task that measures recall of recently presented words.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Each participant saw a list of 20 words (one word every 2 seconds), followed by a 30-second distractor task. Then, they had 1 minute to recall as many words as possible.

StudyObjective: Investigate the neural correlates of four distinct dimensions of Formal Thought Disorder (FTD) in psychosis.
Investigate the neural correlates of trait self-boundarylessness using fMRI tasks and resting-state measures.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were instructed to keep their eyes closed and rest but not fall asleep and to not deliberately meditate.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The first functional run was a resting-state scan lasting 10.43 minutes (350 TRs of 1.8 s each).

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were administered a set of trait adjectives from the Affective Norms of Emotion Words database. The original 20 positive and 20 negative trait adjectives were translated to Swedish by the first author, slightly modified to make the words more relevant in Swedish, and divided into blocks of five words each, which were either all positive or all negative. To each block, one ‘fluid’ word and one ‘constant’ word judged to be of the same valence as the rest of the block were added (total 16 words relating to fluidity/solidity).
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The second functional run was a SRP task, administered through E-prime (Psychological Software Tools). During this task, adapted from , participants were administered a set of trait adjectives from the Affective Norms of Emotion Words database. The original 20 positive and 20 negative trait adjectives were translated to Swedish by the first author, slightly modified to make the words more relevant in Swedish, and divided into blocks of five words each, which were either all positive or all negative. To each block, one ‘fluid’ word and one ‘constant’ word judged to be of the same valence as the rest of the block were added (total 16 words relating to fluidity/solidity).

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: This task was also presented through E-prime and consisted of simple math questions interspersed with presentations of shapes (circle, square, triangle, or arrow). Participants were instructed beforehand to ‘focus on the centre of your experience, the “experiencer” or “observer”’ whenever the arrow was presented.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The third functional run was designed to target the sense of perspectival ownership of experience (hereafter checking-in). This task was also presented through E-prime and consisted of simple math questions interspersed with presentations of shapes (circle, square, triangle, or arrow). Participants were instructed beforehand to ‘focus on the centre of your experience, the “experiencer” or “observer”’ whenever the arrow was presented.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A short-term memory task that measures recall of recently presented words.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Each participant saw a list of 20 words (one word every 2 seconds), followed by a 30-second distractor task. Then, they had 1 minute to recall as many words as possible.

StudyObjective: Accurate localization and coactivation profiles of the frontal eye field and inferior frontal junction: an ALE and MACM fMRI meta-analysis

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants performed tasks requiring the execution of visually guided saccades toward an unpredictable peripheral target and contrasted these activations with a fixation baseline.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The task involved contrasting prosaccades vs fixation and antisaccades vs fixation.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants performed tasks involving rapid serial visual presentation (RSVP) and attentional tasks.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The task involved contrasting oddball vs target trials in covert attention paradigms.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants performed tasks involving switching tasks and task set updating.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The task involved contrasting task-switching vs repetition trials.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants performed tasks involving incongruent vs congruent trials.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The task involved contrasting incongruent vs congruent trials in Stroop paradigms.

StudyObjective: To determine whether reality‐monitoring and self‐monitoring recruit overlapping brain regions, thereby allowing us to deepen our understanding of their common underlying cognitive processes.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were asked to judge whether information was previously self‐generated or derived from outside.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The reality‐monitoring studies included 9 studies with a total of 172 subjects.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were asked to make comparisons between sensory predictions and continuous sensory feedback.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The self‐monitoring studies included 12 studies with a total of 192 subjects.

StudyObjective: Evaluate how neural sensitivity to peer status in adolescents is associated with longitudinal changes in social behaviors.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants viewed yearbook photos of their classmates from school, with the task adapted from previous studies.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The task involved viewing yearbook photos of classmates, with the images selected based on sociometric ratings from previous years.

StudyObjective: Test the prediction that there are dissociable brain networks reflecting the associative strength model and the expectancy model of Pavlovian fear conditioning, consistent with two-system theories of threat and fear reactivity.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants rated their expectancy for shock occurrence during the inter-trial interval.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants used a two-response button box to report their expectancy ratings. When they pressed on the left button, a marker on the screen moved toward the left side of a horizontal scale, and an opposite effect was obtained by pressing on the right button. The rating scale on the screen was divided into seven levels, from '1 = not at all' to '7 = very much so'.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were instructed to pay attention to the face presented in each trial and to rate their expectancy for shock occurrence during the inter-trial interval.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Each trial began by presenting the Likert response task for 3.5s, followed by a variable inter-stimulus interval (ISI) of 2s to 3.5s with a fixation dot before presenting the CS image for 10s. Each trial was followed by a variable inter-trial interval (ITI) of 8.5s to 10s with fixation.

StudyObjective: To determine if iTBS could enhance semantic and executive task processing in healthy middle-aged to older adults.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: A semantic judgment task with varying cognitive demand (low demand: WPM, high demand: FPM).
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants were required to decide whether an auditory stimulus matches with a presented image via yes/no-button press.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: A non-verbal tone judgment task with varying cognitive demand.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants were required to decide whether an auditory stimulus matches with a presented image via yes/no-button press.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A short-term memory task that measures recall of recently presented words.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Participants saw a list of 20 words, did a 30-second distractor task, then recalled as many words as possible within one minute.

StudyObjective: To identify brain regions involved in exploration and exploitation decisions using a coordinate-based meta-analysis.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants make decisions to explore or exploit based on uncertain rewards.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The task involved exploring and exploiting decisions with contrasts between exploration and exploitation.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants rest with eyes open for baseline functional connectivity measurements.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants rested with eyes open for 5 minutes.

StudyObjective: To investigate central pain mechanisms in the context of the gut-brain axis in patients with ulcerative colitis in remission, compared to irritable bowel syndrome and healthy women.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were exposed to painful stimuli from both visceral and somatic modalities, with the aim of elucidating if altered pain processing in chronic visceral pain patients is confined to the GI tract or applies more broadly to other pain modalities.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The study employed a multiple-threat paradigm with visceral and somatic pain stimuli in patients with ulcerative colitis in remission, compared to patients with irritable bowel syndrome and healthy controls.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Structural MRI was used to exclude brain abnormalities and to ensure optimal settings.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Structural MRI was acquired using a 3 Tesla MR scanner with a 32-channel head coil.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants completed a comprehensive psychosocial and clinical symptom questionnaire battery that included assessment of gastrointestinal symptoms, pain, anxiety, depression, and chronic stress.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: The questionnaire battery included assessment of gastrointestinal symptoms and pain severity, anxiety, depression, and chronic stress.

StudyObjective: Examine self-reported rumination in association with rejection-related neural activity and connectivity in adolescent girls.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were asked to classify half of the 60 adolescents' photographs into the peers that they wanted to chat with (liked peers) and another half of the photographs into the peers that they did not want to chat with (unliked peers). At the second visit, in the fMRI scanner, participants received feedback indicating whether each of 60 adolescents were interested in chatting with them (acceptance) or not (rejection) or did not rate their interest (not rated), and reported how receiving this social feedback made them feel.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants were told they were participating in a nationwide study about how teenagers communicate with each other on the internet, and that they would chat online with a peer selected for them based on similar interests from among participants at the other study sites. To enhance believability, participants created an online profile describing their interests and were told they would have their photograph taken.

StudyObjective: Examine adolescents’ neural tracking of peers from their real-world social network that varied in social preferences and popularity.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Adolescents viewed yearbook photos of their peers from their school and grade.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The task was created using E-prime 2.0, and one version was made for each grade level within each school. The associations between likability and popularity ratings across waves 1 and 2 are high, suggesting peer status is highly stable.

StudyObjective: To assess the causal effect of VVGs on the behavioral and neural correlates of empathy and emotional reactivity to violence.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants either received electric stimuli themselves or saw images of the confederate indicating that he was currently receiving electric stimulation. The stimuli were either painful or perceptible but not painful.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants either received electric stimuli themselves or saw images of the confederate indicating that he was currently receiving electric stimulation. The stimuli were either painful or perceptible but not painful.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were shown pictures of either neutral or violent content. Additionally, the pictures depicted either real scenes, or scenes taken from the video game participants played during the gaming sessions.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants were shown pictures of either neutral or violent content. Additionally, the pictures depicted either real scenes, or scenes taken from the video game participants played during the gaming sessions.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A questionnaire designed to measure participants’ trait empathy levels.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Participants completed a questionnaire designed to measure participants’ trait empathy levels.

StudyObjective: To examine whether and how the reward network in the brain is involved in approach versus avoidance goals by using a game-like, intrinsically motivating task.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were instructed that they could win or lose points during the stopwatch task depending on their performance, and their overall goal was to earn the total point of zero or larger than zero at the end of the experiment.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The overall design and procedure is depicted in Fig. . Participants completed a game-like task (the stopwatch task; Murayama et al.,  ,  ; Sakaki et al.,  ) under approach and avoidance goal framing. For each trial, participants were presented with a stopwatch that automatically started; they were asked to press a button to stop the stopwatch within 50 ms of the 5-s time point. If participants stopped the stopwatch within this time window, the trial was deemed a success. In contrast, if participants failed to stop the stopwatch within this time window, the trial was deemed as a failure.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants were asked to rate the level of enjoyment and anxiety that they felt during the block they had just completed, as well as to fill out a retrospective self-report questionnaire about emotional/motivational states they experienced during the approach and avoidance blocks.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Participants’ responses in the self-report questions after each block and at the end of the experiment were compared between the approach and the avoidance conditions.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants were presented with positive/negative words as well as two pictures of stopwatches, one being used in the approach block and the other being used in the avoidance block.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Across seven IAT blocks, participants were asked to press one of the two buttons in response to each of the presented stimuli. In two blocks, positive words and the approach stopwatch were assigned to the same key, while negative words and the avoidance stopwatch were assigned to the other key. If participants had developed a positive attitude toward a stopwatch used in the approach condition, they should be able to respond faster and more accurately when the approach stopwatch was assigned to the same key as positive words than negative words.

StudyObjective: Evaluate the consistency associated with functionally localising reading- and object-sensitive areas of left occipito-temporal cortex.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: A task that requires participants to identify whether a stimulus is identical to the preceding one, with four categories of visual stimuli: written words, pictures of common objects, scrambled pictures of the same objects, and consonant letter strings.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The task was performed in two runs with a block design consisting of 16 trials per category presented every second. A fixation cross was used for 650 ms before the stimulus and another for 350 ms. The stimuli were divided into two lists with counter-balancing across subjects.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants passively viewed or explicitly evaluated mainly textual, sometimes pictorial social scenarios with moral violations/dilemmas. The target conditions were frequently contrasted with neutral or unpleasant social scenarios.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: All areas resulting from the ALE meta-analyses were anatomically labeled by reference to probabilistic cytoarchitectonic maps of the human brain using the SPM Anatomy Toolbox.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants adopted an intentional stance towards others, that is, predict their thoughts, intentions, and future actions. These studies mostly presented cartoons and short narratives that necessitated understanding the beliefs of the acting characters.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: All areas resulting from the ALE meta-analyses were anatomically labeled by reference to probabilistic cytoarchitectonic maps of the human brain using the SPM Anatomy Toolbox.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were supposed to know and “feel into” what another person was feeling. These studies employed mostly visual, sometimes textual or auditory stimuli that conveyed affect-laden social situations which participants watched passively or evaluated on various dimensions.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: All areas resulting from the ALE meta-analyses were anatomically labeled by reference to probabilistic cytoarchitectonic maps of the human brain using the SPM Anatomy Toolbox.

StudyObjective: Investigate the neural correlates of food choice in weight-concerned women.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants made 100 choices between HE and LE snacks while their brains were scanned using fMRI. HE snacks were refused more often than LE snacks.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants viewed one of the study stimuli (3000 ms, choice period) and subsequently had to indicate with a button press (1500 ms, button press period) whether they wanted to eat a portion of the snack or not. During the button press period the words “yes” and “no” were shown left/right (randomized) on the screen. After indicating their choice, a yellow box appeared around the yes or no. Participants were instructed to make their choice already during the period that the image was shown. To ensure that their choices were actually made in direct response to the food pictures, the button press period was so short that it only allowed them to locate whether they had to push the left or right button. The choice trials were interspersed with a random interval (2000 and 5000 ms). At the beginning, halfway (after 50 trials) and at the end an additional baseline period of 30,000 ms was included in the task.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants filled out a questionnaire about an allegedly new type of biscuit, giving ratings of expected tastiness, expected energy content, and to what extent eating the biscuit is appropriate for individuals who are watching their weight.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Participants were instructed that one of the trials counted for real and that they would receive a portion of the snack chosen in that trial at the end of the study session. Eating a HE snack after a short period of fasting is not congruent with the participants' goal to watch their weight. Therefore, self-regulatory success was defined as the percentage of rejected HE snacks.

StudyObjective: Investigate the relationship between GABA concentration and fear-related BOLD responses in the anterior insula.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were presented with images of spiders, animals, negative and neutral IAPS pictures, and were asked to rate the pictures. The paradigm aimed to elicit fear-specific and fear-unspecific BOLD responses.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: A fear provocation paradigm involving the presentation of images of spiders, animals, negative and neutral IAPS pictures, with participants rating the pictures after scanning.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants rated the pictures after scanning using a scale from 1 to 9.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Participants rated the pictures after scanning using a scale from 1 to 9.

StudyObjective: Investigate the neural correlates of reward processing upon scoring a soccer goal and winning money in comparison to reward processing in a monetary incentive task.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants decide to either pass or shoot the ball in a soccer setting, with feedback based on scoring probabilities.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The soccer paradigm involved standard two-versus-one situations in front of a goal, allowing participants to choose between passing or shooting. Feedbacks were preset based on pre-testing ratings.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants guess in which of four boxes a circle is hidden, leading to winning probabilities ranging from 25% to 100%.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants guessed under which of four boxes a circle was hidden, leading to winning probabilities ranging from 25% to 100%. Feedbacks were preset based on the number of boxes shown in each trial.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants were asked to fill out HEXACO PI-R 200 and SVO questionnaires to assess egoism and social value orientation.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Participants handed in the completed personality questionnaires at the scanning appointment and were analyzed using IBM SPSS Statistics 21.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Behavioral data from the soccer paradigm was analyzed to determine the behavior of soccer players in terms of shooting versus passing.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Behavioral data from the soccer paradigm was grouped into four categories (clear and unclear situations, pass and shoot choices).

StudyObjective: Examine how approach and avoidance motivational states affect the neural mechanisms involved in attentional flexibility.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were presented with a large letter composed of several smaller letters (e.g., a T made of smaller Ls), and instructed to indicate with a button press whether the stimulus contained a T or an H. Each composite stimulus contained only one target letter (T or H), which was presented as either the large letter (global target) or the small letters (local target).
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Each trial began with a fixation cross presented for 1000 ms, followed by the motivation-inducing image for 750 ms. The fixation cross appeared again, for a randomly-jittered interval, with a gamma distribution and mean time of 500 ms. Next, the composite letter stimulus was presented for 1500 ms. Only responses provided within this 1500 ms window were included in the analyses.

StudyObjective: To explore the hypothesis that the role of the DMN in higher order cognition is to allow cognition to be shaped by information from stored representations rather than information in the immediate environment.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants alternate between tasks where they either make decisions about the location of shapes as they are presented on screen (0-back) or with respect to their location on the prior trial (1-back).
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The task involves observing non-colored shapes presented at fixation waiting for the presentation of a colored slide at which point they would indicate using a button press which side of the fixation cross a target shape was.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants alternate between tasks where they either make decisions about the location of shapes as they are presented on screen (0-back) or with respect to their location on the prior trial (1-back).
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The task involves observing non-colored shapes presented at fixation waiting for the presentation of a colored slide at which point they would indicate using a button press which side of the fixation cross a target shape was.

StudyObjective: Investigate the neural substrate of typewriting and compare it with that of writing.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Involves typing visually presented Japanese words on a modified Fujitsu CP218230-02 keyboard.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Subjects were instructed to type words using the alphabetical input method, with no linguistic structure or repeated bigrams in the output.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Involves writing words with the right index finger in the air, resembling the way Japanese people often write.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Subjects were instructed to trace each word in the air with their index finger in Japanese phonograms (kana).

StudyObjective: Investigate how preferences for the giver modulate understanding of the gift’s meaning.

StudyObjective: Isolate aspects of the decision process that cognitively and neurally distinguish casual MA users from non-users, in order to inform future treatment development.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants had to decide whether to accept or refuse a series of mixed gambles. In each trial participants were presented with a set of cups (3 to 11). They were informed that one of the cups contained a gain (amount ranging between $3 and $8) and the rest of the cups contained a loss of $1, and they were asked to accept or reject the gamble. When the gamble was accepted, the participant was informed of the gain or loss after a short waiting period. When the gamble was rejected, the participant did not win or lose any money. When no selection was made during the response window, the participant lost $1.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The CUPS task was similarly used to examine neurocognitive characteristics specific to individuals with internet gambling disorder (IGD) during the decision process.
TaskMetrics: amount or number of wins or losses

StudyObjective: Evaluate the efficacy of weight loss intervention using early alterations of fMRI food cue reactivity in the striatum.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Measure fMRI responses to high- and low-calorie food images in the striatum.

TaskMetrics: fMRI responses to high- vs. low-calorie food images

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants were asked to decide whether the given image was seen (old) or not seen (new) in the scanner.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Participants completed an old/new recognition memory task outside the scanner following each fMRI session.

StudyObjective: To understand the neural basis of N400 and how it is affected by SZ.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants indicated whether a word was a semantic match or non-match to the preceding picture.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: In this task, a simple line drawing of an object is presented (250 ms), and following a short delay (75 ms), a word appears. Subjects are instructed to respond by indicating whether the word was a semantic match (50% of trials) or non-match (50% of trials) to the preceding picture. Pictures consisted of 102 line drawings selected from ( ) and classified into 10 natural categories (clothing, animal, bird, appliance, tool, vehicle, vegetable, fruit, toy, and musical instrument). The full set of pictures comprised a block of 102 trials which was repeated across a total of four blocks, with the order of pictures varying across blocks. Half of the unmatched trials comprised picture-word pairs from a related semantic category (related co-hyponym, e.g., APPLE →lemon) and the other half comprised picture-word pairs from unrelated semantic categories (unrelated, e.g., APPLE →cow). Subjects were not asked to distinguish between related and unrelated unmatched target words. Occasional null events were inserted between trials, resulting in trial-to-trial intervals that ranged from 3 to 11 s. Participants performed several practice trials prior to ERP or fMRI recordings. No feedback was given to signal performance accuracy and participants were told to respond as quickly as possible without sacrificing accuracy. All subjects performed the task at >90% accuracy (See Supplementary Table 1. HC = 95.0% and SZ = 91.8%, F(1,45) = 5.7295,   p   = 0.02). We found no effect of practice across the two sessions, performance accuracy was similar for the first and second session across groups (paired   t  -test, t-stat = −0.70,   p   = 0.49) and remained insignificant after controlling for the time difference between sessions (p = 0.49). Moreover, there was no effect of session order or time between sessions on the loading weight of the joint component reported below (ANCOVA model with covariates of group, session order and times between sessions). Reaction latency data were collected, and the median reaction times per subject, per condition (matched, unmatched) was determined (see Supplementary Methods and Results). All participants showed slower reaction times during the fMRI session than EEG session (see Supplementary Fig. 1) without higher level interaction effects between Group (HC or SZ) or Session (EEG or fMRI).

fMRITasks.DesignDetails: After recursive elimination of 99.9% of the features, leave-one-subject-out cross-validated accuracy at a c-value of 10 yielded a classification rate of 60%. Projecting this remaining 0.1% of the selected features back into standardized brain space revealed negative features in the ventral striatum, which overlapped with the predefined NAcc VOI.

BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Hit rates were measured across both groups, with no significant difference in hit rates.

fMRITasks.DesignDetails: In this study, the Go/No-Go task included 4 blocks, each with 30 trials. Each trial lasted 2 seconds, with a 1-second inter-trial interval. Subjects were instructed to press a button upon seeing 'go' stimuli and to refrain from pressing for 'no-go' stimuli.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Subjects rested with eyes open for baseline functional connectivity measurements.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants completed a 5-minute resting-state scan in a single continuous run, instructed to keep their eyes open and minimize movement.

StudyObjective: Investigate the neural substrates of the influence of emotional cues on cognitive control in risk-taking adolescents.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were shown a target emotion (calm, happy, or angry) and were instructed to press a button when shown a 'go' (target) stimulus and to inhibit their response by not pressing the button when shown a 'no-go' (non-target) stimulus.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The task was presented in Presentation using a projection screen and mirror within the head coil. Responses were recorded using a response box attached to the participant’s respiratory belt. Participants responded with their right index finger.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants draw from a deck of cards, with each card earning or losing them points. The amount of gain and loss and the number of loss cards in the deck vary across trials.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: The task was presented in Presentation using a projection screen and mirror within the head coil. Responses were recorded using a response box attached to the participant’s respiratory belt. Participants responded with their right index finger.

StudyObjective: Investigate the development of the body-selective areas in the visual cortex and their modulation by emotion by comparing brain activity in adults, adolescents and children passively viewing angry, happy and neutral body movements, as well as objects’ movements.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants passively viewed short videos of angry, happy or neutral body movements.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants viewed videos depicting one actor, dressed in black against a green background, moving in an angry, happy or neutral manner. Six actors were males and nine females, with each actor recorded three times for each of the three emotions. The videos were recorded using a digital video camera and were edited to two-second long clips (50 frames at 25 frames per second).

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants rested with eyes open for baseline functional connectivity measurements.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants completed a 5-minute resting-state scan in a single continuous run, instructed to keep their eyes open and minimize movement.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants were given a short forced-choice emotion recognition task using the same stimuli to gauge their understanding of the emotional content of the stimuli.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Some of the subjects (16 children, 15 adolescents and 18 adults) also participated in another independent 8-min functional scan during the same scanning session, before completing the structural scans.

StudyObjective: Investigate the neural correlates of strategic decision making when the participant must consider an opponent’s inferences about the participant’s own beliefs in a bilateral manner.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants played an economic game with three types of opponents: a human opponent outside the scanner, an artificial agent that followed a fixed probabilistic strategy according to a game-theoretic solution (FIX) and an artificial agent that adjusted its choices through a machine-learning algorithm (LRN).
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants’ choice behaviors against the human opponent and LRN were similar but remarkably different from those against FIX.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A short-term memory task that measures recall of recently presented words.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Each participant saw a list of 20 words (one word every 2 seconds), followed by a 30-second distractor task. Then, they had 1 minute to recall as many words as possible.

StudyObjective: Examine the relationship between sleep disruption‐induced pain sensitivity and functional connectivity of cognitive networks contributing to pain modulation.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants performed a simple motor task designed to elicit intrinsic network connectivity without the risk of participants falling asleep.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants engaged in a simple task that involved using their response box. They looked up and saw a screen with an arrow pointing either left or right. When the right facing arrow flashed, they should press 3 (the button farthest to the right). When the left facing arrow flashed, they should press 1 (the button farthest to the left).

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants underwent a noxious thermal stimulation task with pain ratings and stimulus temperatures used to derive the pain sensitivity change score.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The thermal stimuli were presented concomitant with music of neutral valence. Pain ratings were made following the delivery of each noxious thermal stimulus, which ended at the same time the music clip ended.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A short-term memory task that measures recall of recently presented words.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Each participant saw a list of 20 words (one word every 2 seconds), followed by a 30-second distractor task. Then, they had 1 minute to recall as many words as possible within one minute.

StudyObjective: To examine brain activation related to parenting and emotion regulation in parent-adolescent dyads during concurrent fMRI scanning with a novel task – the Testing Emotional Attunement and Mutuality (TEAM) task.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants completed the task while simultaneously undergoing fMRI scanning. The TEAM task is an event-related design and consists of 17 trials during which participants first see a pattern of colored arrows presented sequentially on the screen for 3 s, twice in a row (totaling 6 s). They are then given 4 s to reconstruct the sequence by pressing colored buttons on a response box. At the end of the 4-s response window, participants see a message with feedback regarding both dyad members’ performance on that trial. Prior to the scan, participants are told that if one or both members of the parent-adolescent dyad respond incorrectly to a trial, they will lose $5 from a starting amount of $50.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants were scanned simultaneously while each performing the TEAM task. The TEAM task consists of trials during which a pattern of four arrows is displayed twice to the participant, and the participant then enters the pattern from memory using a handheld response box. Participants are then provided feedback about both their own and their partner’s performance. Unbeknownst to the participant, however, the feedback for their partner’s performance has been pre-programmed to either show a correct (14 trials per run) or incorrect (three trials per run) response. Scanners are located in close physical proximity separated by a shared control room.

StudyObjective: Investigate the neural correlates of empathy for pain using fMRI tasks and behavioral assessments.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were presented with a cue indicating the upcoming pain intensity and saw a photo of the shock recipient on the screen. A brief electrical shock was delivered during self-directed trials.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants were presented with a cue indicating the upcoming pain intensity and saw a photo of the shock recipient on the screen. A brief electrical shock was delivered during self-directed trials.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants rated how similar they perceived the confederate to be, and how much they liked the other person.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Participants rated how similar they perceived the confederate to be, and how much they liked the other person.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants completed the Interpersonal Reactivity Index online prior to the start of the experiment.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Participants completed the Interpersonal Reactivity Index online prior to the start of the experiment.

StudyObjective: Investigate the neural correlates of private-public mappings in human prefrontal cortex.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Subjects performed a social perceptual decision task requiring them to adapt how they communicated their confidence about a perceptual decision to the social context.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Subjects made a perceptual group decision with one of four partners, varying the fraction of coherently moving dots to manipulate subjects' internal sense of confidence. The task was performed in a behavioural session and subsequently during fMRI.

StudyObjective: To examine whether individuals' chronological age could be predicted from T1 MRI scan and whether it is possible to localize the underlying brain regions that allow such prediction.

Examine how conformity decisions are evaluated in the developing brain and unfold across social contexts, particularly when adolescents’ own opinions conflict with the opinions of their parents, peers, or both.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were presented with opposing attitudes from their parent and peer, which were manipulated based on the participant’s original rating during the behavioral session. On Parent Conflict trials, just the parent’s rating conflicted from the participant’s but the peer’s rating matched. On Peer Conflict trials, just the peer’s rating conflicted from the participant’s but the parent’s rating matched. On Mutual Conflict trials, both the parent’s and peer’s ratings conflicted from the participant’s original rating.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants completed the Attitude Conformity task during fMRI. On each trial, participants first viewed a behavior they previously rated (but were not reminded of their original ratings). Following a jittered inter-stimulus interval (2 s), participants were then shown their parents’ and peers’ ratings on each behavior and instructed to choose which person they agreed with most.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A short-term memory task that measures recall of recently presented words.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Each participant saw a list of 20 words (one word every 2 seconds), followed by a 30-second distractor task. Then, they had 1 minute to recall as many words as possible.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants imagine themselves in a novel social event and report their anticipatory cognitions and emotions.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Participants complete a 10-item inventory examining social reward and threat expectancies.

fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants viewed unhealthy craved foods, unhealthy not-craved foods, or healthy vegetables. For unhealthy craved foods, participants either actively viewed the foods or reappraised their craving for them.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were screened for MRI contraindications and instructed on the requirements of the study. Weight and height were measured, after which participants took part in an MRI session.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The baseline session was conducted to screen participants for MRI contraindications and to measure weight and height.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A 67-item self-report measure of cravings for and liking of specific foods.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Participants were asked to rate the frequency of cravings for the past 30 days on a 5-point Likert scale and how much they liked each food on a 4-point Likert scale.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: An Automated Self-Administered 24 h (ASA24) Dietary Assessment Tool which allows for the calculation of the Healthy Eating Index (HEI);
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Eating behavior was assessed via the ASA24 twice at each time point to obtain a more representative estimate of daily eating behavior.

StudyObjective: Investigate the relevance of the hippocampus for conflict-induced memory improvement.

fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants performed a face-word Stroop task with congruent and incongruent distractor words, with a 5000 ms pseudo-exponentially distributed inter-trial interval.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants rated previously seen faces as old or new within a 30-45 minute delay outside of the MRI scanner.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants rated faces as definitely old, probably old, probably new, or definitely new.

fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The task includes 180 events grouped into 32 blocks, with eight rest blocks, eight isolated auditory blocks, eight isolated visual blocks, and eight parallel auditory/visual blocks.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants recall previously encoded items from auditory and visual stimuli after a 10-minute fMRI acquisition time.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: The task includes 160 previously encoded (old) and 160 novel (new) items in an auditory and visual recognition test.

fMRITasks.DesignDetails: During attentive listening, participants were asked to stay alert, still, and keep their eyes focused on a fixation cross while listening to a sequence of auditory sounds, including words, silence, and noise.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were asked to do the same as in attentive listening, with the addition of repeating the word they just heard aloud.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: During word repetition, participants’ spoken responses were recorded using an in-bore Fibersound optical microphone. These responses were scored for accuracy offline by a research assistant.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants perform antisaccades to faces or cars, requiring inhibitory control to switch saccades.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants viewed 2 types of stimuli: faces or cars, and were instructed to look toward the appearing stimulus (prosaccade) or in the opposite direction (antisaccade).

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants rest inside the MRI scanner with eyes open for baseline functional connectivity measurements.

StudyObjective: Investigated the way the brain deals with an important mental workload and/or a threat situation.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants had to compute an exact arithmetic result to compare it with the target obtained two trials before.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The task was developed to combine a classical n‐back task with mental arithmetic. Instead of memorizing and comparing unique items, as in the classical n‐back task, the participants had to memorize and to compare the results of arithmetic operations, computed beforehand.

fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants could give away 1, 2, or 3 out of 7 coins in the small giving condition and 4, 5, or 6 out of 7 coins in the large giving condition.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were asked to determine whether the current target was identical to the stimulus that appeared two trials earlier in the Classification task.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: 2Back-SWi trials were divided into two types: where the target domain was relevant to the preceding 2Back trials (Classification-SWr, e.g., the number 2Back-SW trial following successive number Classification trials), and where this condition was switched (Classification-SWi, e.g., the number 2Back-SW trial following consecutive letter Classification trials).

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were asked to classify the target stimuli, printed in red, based on their characteristics (i.e., odd/even or vowel/consonant).
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Classification-SWi trials were divided into two types: where the target domain was relevant to the preceding 2Back trials (Classification-SWr, e.g., the number Classification-SW following number 2Back trials), and where this condition was switched (Classification-SWi, e.g., the number Classification-SW following letter 2Back trials).

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were asked to classify the target stimuli, printed in red, based on their characteristics (i.e., odd/even or vowel/consonant).

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were asked to classify the target stimuli, printed in red, based on their characteristics (i.e., odd/even or vowel/consonant).

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants were instructed to generate appropriate alternative uses for three common objects: 'Brick,' 'Key,' and 'Newspaper.' They recorded as many uses as possible for each item within 2 minutes using a paper and pen.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: The fluency score was calculated by counting the number of correct solutions. The flexibility score was computed by counting the number of different solution categories. The originality score for each response was computed by dividing the percentage of the given response over the set of entire responses. The different points were then assigned to individual responses according to their percentages (< 1%: 2 points; < 5%: 1 point; and ≥ 5%: 0 points). The points for each of the three objects were summed and divided by the number of correct responses.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A horizontal array of five white arrows in the center of the screen was presented on a black background. The middle arrow was the target while the others were non-target distractors. The task required participants to respond to the direction of the target with a left or right button press as quickly and accurately as possible while ignoring distractors.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: The stimuli were presented for 500 ms with a fixation cross presented as an ITI in the middle of the screen for 2000 ms. The interference effect, which represents an individual’s ability to focus their attention on an external stimulus, was measured by subtracting the mean retention times (RTs) of congruent trials from those of incongruent trials.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Stimuli for the response switching task consisted of four even numbers (2, 4, 6, and 8) and four odd (3, 5, 7, and 9), which were colored either green or red. Participants were asked to classify the targets as odd or even by pressing their left or right buttons, respectively, when the target color was green; their responses were then reversed when the target was red.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: The task included 40 switch trials and 120 repeat trials. The stimuli were presented for 500 ms with a fixation cross presented as an ITI in the middle of the screen for 2000 ms. The switch cost, which indicates individual differences in behavioral flexibility, was measured by subtracting the mean RTs of repeat trials from those of switch trials.

To examine whether lonely individuals have a reduced ability to synchronize with others and explore the neural activation related to synchronization in high and low loneliness individuals.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: A computer-based movement synchronization multiagent paradigm where participants interact nonverbally by controlling the movement of circle-shaped figures with different colors. The task includes three conditions: random, free, and synchronized movement.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants were scanned using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) while interacting nonverbally by controlling the movement of differently colored circles. The task included three conditions: random, free, and synchronized movement.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants rated their enjoyment of the game throughout the task.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants’ enjoyment ratings in each of the blocks were used to calculate an average enjoyment score in each condition for each participant.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants completed the UCLA loneliness scale to assess levels of loneliness.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Participants filled out the UCLA loneliness scale during screening, and then two groups were recruited, based on their loneliness score.

StudyObjective: Investigate the neural correlates of cognitive control processes using fMRI tasks and behavioral assessments.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: A classic inhibitory control task measuring both reaction time and error rates in response to no-go stimuli.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: In this study, the Go/No-Go task included 4 blocks, each with 30 trials. Each trial lasted 2 seconds, with a 1-second inter-trial interval. Subjects were instructed to press a button upon seeing 'go' stimuli and to refrain from pressing for 'no-go' stimuli.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Subjects rested with eyes open for baseline functional connectivity measurements.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants completed a 5-minute resting-state scan in a single continuous run, instructed to keep their eyes open and minimize movement.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A short-term memory task that measures recall of recently presented words.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Each participant saw a list of 20 words (one word every 2 seconds), followed by a 30-second distractor task. Then, they had 1 minute to recall as many words as possible.
